video.title: Rocks and Sand and Awesome Scientists 2
video.story: To provide children with background knowledge about the concept "matter takes up space," the teacher asked her students to predict what would happen to rocks in a jar when sand was poured on top of them. In this video, children have created drawings to illustrate their predictions and are gathered for a group discussion.
video.standards: Materials come in different forms (states), including solids, liquids, and gases. As a basis for understanding this concept: a. Students know solids, liquids, and gases have different properties. b. Students know the properties of substances can change when the substances are mixed, cooled, or heated.

planningCuepoints.cuepoint: With the foundation of the lesson planned in formal planning, the teacher asks children to make predictions and discuss them. This requires the teacher to use flexibility as she listens to children and builds on their ideas.

The children's predictions provide an assessment of their prior knowledge, which helps the teacher plan firsthand experiences related to the concepts. Later the children will use their predictions as references during and after conducting an experiment.

Although the teacher does not know what the children are going to say, she knows what the big idea is and chooses certain students' responses to either help highlight the learning goal or point out misconceptions. Notice, also, how she creates a rich and meaningful discussion by calling on children from different cultural and linguistic backgrounds and including both boys and girls.

setupCuepoints.cuepoint: The teacher works with a small group of children on the rug. They sit in a circle, which helps include everyone in the discussion.
Note that the representation and the experiment use simple materials such as marbles, sand, water, markers, and paper.

experiencesCuepoints.cuepoint: The children have had prior experiences with sorting and categorizing solids by their properties, such as texture, weight, size and shape and by their characteristics, rough, heavy, small and round.

Making predictions and discussing them helps provide background knowledge that prepares children for the secondhand experience that will follow. This helps them become more selective in their observations of the secondhand experience and focuses their attention on the concept, which is matter takes up space.

representationCuepoints.cuepoint: The teacher encourages the child to discuss her two dimensional representation. The child's response will help the teacher assess the student's understanding of the concept.
The children accompany their two dimensional representations with oral or textual representations or both.
Asking clarifying questions helps the teacher assess the child's understanding.
Repeating the child's words and asking a follow-up question reinforces a good observation and helps move the child forward in her understanding.

cultureCuepoints.cuepoint: Notice how the teacher refers to the child as a scientist. This helps the child see herself as a scientist, which in turn builds confidence and competence.

Here the teacher helps a shy, quiet child feel safe explaining her work to her peers. She does this by letting the child finish her explanation even when it's inaudible to others, preventing other children from interrupting, and respectfully asking the child to repeat her explanation for the rest of the group.
Notice how the teacher calls attention to the concept by pausing the conversation and repeating the child's words to the group. This also reinforces the scientific lexicon.

Notice how the teacher makes an English Language learner feel comfortable discussing her ideas in front of her peers. She does this by calling on the child last, which gives the child time to observe others interacting with the teacher. The teacher also asks open-ended questions for which there is no wrong answer.

video.title: The Roller Coaster 2
video.story: During their study of simple machines, force and motion, and kinetic and potential energy, students decided to build a roller coaster that sends messages from one classroom to another. In this video, two children are working on the roller coaster model.
video.standards: The motion of objects can be observed and measured. As a basis for understanding this concept: a. Students know the position of an object can be described by locating it in relation to another object or to the background. b. Students know an object's motion can be described by recording the change in position of the object over time. c. Students know the way to change how something is moving is by giving it a push or a pull. The size of the change is related to the strength, or the amount of force, of the push or pull. d. Students know tools and machines are used to apply pushes and pulls (forces) to make things move. e. Students know objects fall to the ground unless something holds them up.

planningCuepoints.cuepoint: Planning for a project involves teachers deciding what materials will be needed to implement the children's ideas. In this example, the teacher also planned to have the students bring scrap materials in from home so that they would be available for use in building the roller coaster.

Students' interests, such as the need to support the ramp they are working on, can lead to effective ideas and projects that are related to the concepts. In fact, this entire roller coaster project was designed by the children to send messages between two classrooms.

Next you will hear the teacher struggling with the challenges inherent in planning which activities to monitor and which students to allow freedom in their work as she aims to have all of the students work productively.

setupCuepoints.cuepoint: The roller coaster has been mounted on the windows outside the classroom, making the outdoor space an extension of the learning environment. The model remains here while in progress so that the students can continually examine it and add to it as they learn more about the concepts being studied.
Materials consist of a variety of donated scraps such as chains, empty containers and blocks of wood. Using donated or found materials keeps project costs low and inspires ingenuity.
Materials for the project are readily accessible to the children so that they can easily experiment with them as they search for the best supplies to complete their model.

experiencesCuepoints.cuepoint: Because this is a 3-D model, it is both conceptual and a firsthand experience where the students can see the issues involved in using simple machines such as ramps, and explore the concepts of force and motion. This experience can also lead to new conjectures about motion, such as when this student says, "when it goes slow, it stays just fine."

Having a firsthand experience with a model leads the students to new questions such as "Why does it [the ball] go down?" It also gives them tools to experiment and to attempt to find the answers to their questions.

representationCuepoints.cuepoint: Building a 3-D structure such as a roller coaster provides a natural way to explore the properties of force and motion and kinetic and potential energy.
As the children repeatedly test their roller coaster they make revisions to help the message ball roll through one section more effectively.
In each representation different materials are offered. Here the children choose the materials. At other times the teacher makes the choice.

cultureCuepoints.cuepoint: Although a teacher is present to supervise, the children are trusted to work on testing and improving the model roller coaster. They are able to work independently and productively because the teachers have set up routines to support this and children have had much practice working together.

Children work together, negotiating, discussing and planning. Having well-established social routines and offering frequent opportunities to collaborate help children develop and practice these skills.
When the children tell the teacher they need something to hold up the tubes, she doesn't solve the problem for them. She gives them encouragement to do the work on their own.

video.title: Make Your Body a Rough Piece of Wood
video.story: Children have spent time using their senses to experience the different states of matter and have developed a scientific lexicon to describe the properties and characteristics of solids, liquids, and gases. After representing each state of matter by sketching, sculpting with clay, and using the computer, the teacher asks her students to use their bodies to represent different characteristics of a solid.
video.standards:
1. Properties of materials can be observed, measured, and predicted. As a basis for understanding this concept:
  • Students know objects can be described in terms of the materials they are made of (e.g., clay, cloth, paper) and their physical properties (e.g., color, size, shape, weight, texture, flexibility, attraction to magnets, floating, sinking).
    • 2. Materials come in different forms (states), including solids, liquids, and gases. As a basis for understanding this concept:
  • Students know solids, liquids, and gases have different properties.

planningCuepoints.cuepoint: The teacher planned this additional experience with kinesthetic representation for children who needed reinforcement of their understanding of characteristics of solids.

The teacher makes decisions about which characteristics of solids she will model and which ones she will ask the children to model based on her learning goals for the children and to highlight important contrasts.

setupCuepoints.cuepoint: Ample space is provided for children to move around freely.
The teacher is using an empty auditorium for this lesson, but any space where children can move freely, such as part of a playground, would work.
The children are able to observe the teachers' representations from different angles.

experiencesCuepoints.cuepoint: Before creating kinesthetic representations, children have had experiences with the states of matter and developed a scientific lexicon to describe the properties and characteristics of solids, liquids and gases.

The teacher's model creates a secondhand experience for the children to see the characteristics of the solid. This could be a reminder of the expository and fictional texts containing words such as "pointy," "rough" and "smooth" that the children read previously.

representationCuepoints.cuepoint: The teacher uses kinesthetic representation immediately following a discussion of words that describe some physical characteristics of matter.
The teacher reinforces the scientific lexicon by using it to describe what she sees.
Children are given the opportunity to observe other students' representations and to revise their own.

cultureCuepoints.cuepoint: Working with a small group of children creates a more immediate and intimate experience where all students have access to the teacher and the teacher can observe all the students.
When the teacher names the students and verbally acknowledges their work, she makes them feel included and encourages their participation.
Children are encouraged to observe each others' representations.

video.standards: The motion of objects can be observed and measured. As a basis for understanding this concept: a. Students know the position of an object can be described by locating it in relation to another object or to the background. b. Students know an object's motion can be described by recording the change in position of the object over time. c. Students know the way to change how something is moving is by giving it a push or a pull. The size of the change is related to the strength, or the amount of force, of the push or pull. d. Students know tools and machines are used to apply pushes and pulls (forces) to make things move. e. Students know objects fall to the ground unless something holds them up.

planningCuepoints.cuepoint: Notice that the teacher's questions are planned to take advantage of what this type of representation is good at - namely, getting at why and how the water makes the water wheel move.
The teacher's original plan did not include focusing on water wheels. Children's interest provided an opportunity to make a meaningful connection with the concepts.
A strong knowledge of the content helps teachers assess students' conceptual understanding, correct their misperceptions and guide them to the learning goals.

setupCuepoints.cuepoint: Ample rug space allows the children to assemble comfortably for a discussion. By sitting low to the ground, the teacher conveys a sense of sharing rather than testing.
The teacher holds the book up and moves it around so that all the children can see it.

experiencesCuepoints.cuepoint: Ample rug space allows the children to assemble comfortably for a discussion. By sitting low to the ground, the teacher conveys a sense of sharing rather than testing.
Discussing prior experiences with water wheels helps build children's knowledge to create new understanding of the concepts.

representationCuepoints.cuepoint: Discussing text offers children the opportunity to increase their scientific lexicon and practice using it in context. The child's statement that "water has gravity in it" provides an assessment of the child's understanding.
The teacher facilitates the discussion by pointing out key ideas that the children have brought up and connecting their ideas to the concepts.
Children have the opportunity to create new knowledge by building on their prior knowledge and experiences.

cultureCuepoints.cuepoint: By posing a question and immediately saying, "Don't call out. Raise hands," the teacher creates an opportunity for children to think and gives everyone a chance to answer.
Asking, "What do you think?" offers the child a platform for discussing his ideas.
When the teacher asks if others agree with the student's idea, she helps build consensus but also leaves open the possibility for other thoughts.

Students know tools and machines are used to apply pushes and pulls (forces) to make things move. e. Students know objects fall to the ground unless something holds them up.

planningCuepoints.cuepoint: At first the teacher does not give the children the proper tools to make their work easier. Instead she has planned the experience so that children can discover firsthand how difficult it is to perform the task without simple machines.
The teacher has chosen materials that illustrate the concept that simple machines make work easier. She provides a variety of materials and tools, such as clay, wood, hammers, nails and rolling pins.

setupCuepoints.cuepoint: The students' work is completed in small groups, where they can hear and see each others' activities.
The tools are in a central place where all children can access them without assistance.
The book on the table provides a ready source of information about simple machines that children can easily access.
In both classrooms, teachers make use of the entire space, setting up small groups at tables and allowing children to move around as they pursue their work.

experiencesCuepoints.cuepoint: First children are asked to work with wood and nails using only their hands.

Next, the children will be given the opportunity to experience using tools to make work easier. As the children are beginning, the teacher will focus them on the task by reminding them of the concept.
After the children have had the experience, the teacher will remind them again of the concept. Both the work assigned and the teacher's commentary ask the children to be explicit about the concept.

representationCuepoints.cuepoint: The student uses text and drawing to represent her understanding that simple machines require less energy than doing the same task manually.
The teacher talks with the student to help her reflect on the experience and link it to the concepts.

cultureCuepoints.cuepoint: Working together in small groups, the children share their experiences and their observations.
Notice that the teacher sits with the children, at their level, so he can engage them in conversation about their work.

Notice that the children are trusted to use tools such as hammers and nails, and they use them responsibly. This is possible because the teachers have established routines to accustom children to working independently.

planningCuepoints.cuepoint: The teacher has structured the introduction of the concepts so that children first made predictions and now are engaging in a secondhand experience. This helps give the children an investment in the experiment as they watch to see how their predictions compare to the results.

setupCuepoints.cuepoint: The group sits in a circle, which encourages discussion and interaction.
The demonstration uses simple and inexpensive materials--rocks, sand, marbles, water and glass jars.
The children are encouraged to move around the space and to position themselves so they can closely observe the rocks and water.

experiencesCuepoints.cuepoint: The teacher gathers the children for a secondhand experience, which helps make the science concepts more memorable because they can see the way the physical principles play out.
The teacher asks lots of questions to engage children's attention and focus the experience on the concepts.
Asking "What's happening?" cues the children to observe closely and helps them develop analytical skills.

The animation in the teacher's voice helps engage the children in the secondhand experience. In secondhand experiences, teachers have to work harder to summon children's attention. This is different from firsthand experiences, where the tension is built into the experience.

representationCuepoints.cuepoint: Before the demonstration, the teacher asked the children to predict what would happen and to create 2-D representations of their thinking.

cultureCuepoints.cuepoint: As the teacher conducts the experiment, she asks the children to share their ideas and observations. Fostering a classroom culture in which students are expected to take turns and to listen actively and respectfully encourages participation.

Notice that the teacher refers back to the child's comment, mentioning him by name. In an effective classroom ecosystem, teachers and children are partners in the learning process and build off each others' ideas.

Notice that the children are free to sit comfortably, and some even lie on the floor. Well established routines and expectations for behavior make it possible for the group to work in this way. By encouraging children to move around so they can see, the teacher helps deepen the children's engagement in the experience.

planningCuepoints.cuepoint: In her planning, the teacher decided to read the book between firsthand and secondhand experiences to both reinforce and foreshadow the experiences. In this case, she's using the book to help focus on the scientific lexicon of the states of matter.
The teacher does an initial assessment of the students' background knowledge of gas as one of the states of matter.

setupCuepoints.cuepoint: With thirdhand experiences it is possible to gather children in larger groups. However, it is necessary to work harder to focus children's attention. The animation in the teacher's voice helps engage the children in the thirdhand experience.
The whole-group area is large enough for two classrooms to sit together comfortably. This was achieved by pushing away some of the furniture temporarily.

experiencesCuepoints.cuepoint: The teacher uses a thirdhand experience, reading a book about the states of matter, to reinforce what the children have learned through firsthand experiences.

The animation in the teacher's voice helps engage the children in the thirdhand experience. In thirdhand experiences teachers have to work harder to summon children's attention. This is different from firsthand experiences, where the tension is built into the experience.
To highlight and bring attention to the concepts and the scientific lexicon, the teacher uses inflection and asks the children questions.

representationCuepoints.cuepoint: With the exception of the teacher inviting children to call out words, children are not creating representations here. Their learning and practicing the scientific lexicon will support their later representation.

cultureCuepoints.cuepoint: Bringing the children together in a large group allows them to share their experiences and knowledge as they discuss the book. Later, when they work in small groups, they can refer back to their shared experience of the story.

The teacher uses questions to engage the children in the story and focus their attention on the crucial information at the right moments. Having the children assist in reading the material helps reinforce their understanding of the concept.

video.title: Alex Being Forthright - and Mistaken
video.concept: Energy is stored and energy is released
video.story: In the sequence before this video begins, the teacher had asked children to label their roller coaster at the points where the ball achieves maximum kinetic and potential energy. When Alex explains his placement of the labels, it becomes apparent that he is confusing velocity with the distinction between kinetic and potential energy. The teacher recognizes this and makes a plan to help him refine his understanding. (For more on how she and her colleague re-teach the concepts to clear up the misconceptions, go to the Example Video in Flexible Planning.)
video.standards: The concepts here go beyond the standards, but it was important to address them because they came up in the context of the project.

This is kinetic energy, because potential energy is energy that is gaining energy, and kinetic is leaving energy.

Because it's losing speed.

Yeah.

--I know.

They had stickers that said "potential energy," one of them said, and the other one said "kinetic."

planningCuepoints.cuepoint: The idea to build a roller coaster was generated by the children. The teachers did careful planning to align the project with the concepts and big ideas.

The teacher planned this time to work with a small group of students to assess their understanding of the concepts of kinetic and potential energy. Meanwhile, a teaching assistant and a parent volunteer work with the other children on another aspect of the roller coaster project.

After realizing the students in the small group were confused about the concepts, the teacher brought the discussion to the whole group. This required flexibility in planning and a willingness to allow the children's needs to influence the course of instruction.
After this discussion, the teacher will do additional planning with her colleagues to clarify her own understanding of the scientific concepts and determine how best to clarify them for the students.

setupCuepoints.cuepoint: When setting up a large project, consider all aspects of the learning environment. Using outdoor space, when possible, provides opportunities for small group work and allows for in-depth, uninterrupted discussion.

Throughout the work space, resources are accessible to all the children. Note the canisters of building materials on the countertop. When the camera zooms out, notice the paint bottles to the left of the sink and the materials in storage tables at the far right. These important supplies are stored at children's height and are available as they need them.

The roller coaster is mounted on the outside of the classroom windows and remains there for the duration of the project. Displaying on-going work helps stimulate thinking, creativity and discussion, and integrates the project into the life of the classroom.

Notice the photos displayed behind the roller coaster. They tell the story of the project thus far. Displaying documentation of the group's planning and thinking process provides context for the project, gives teachers and children opportunities for reflection, and offers parents a way to connect with the children's work.

Student work, including paintings depicting force and motion, is displayed prominently in the classroom. The displays help stimulate thinking, create dialogue and convey that the children's work is valued.

experiencesCuepoints.cuepoint: The children began building the roller coaster toward the end of the school year, but they had been building knowledge of the concepts since September. For example, a trip to a local amusement park allowed the children to explore the concepts of force and motion and kinetic and potential energy through firsthand experiences with roller coasters.
The students have firsthand experiences as they use the roller coaster model to apply their knowledge of the concepts.

The children are able to discuss scientific ideas because they have had many experiences throughout the year that were designed to familiarize them with the concepts. These included building and testing model inclined planes and experimenting with simple machines.

representationCuepoints.cuepoint: Using their knowledge of the concepts, the students have built a 3-D working model of a roller coaster. A student uses text to label the roller coaster where he thinks kinetic and potential energy are at work.

As the student explains his reasoning for labeling the parts of the roller coaster, he finds he is confused about the concepts. Having children talk about their work is an excellent way to assess their understanding and provides an opportunity to clarify the concepts.
Notice the paintings displayed above and to the right of the white board. They are 2-D representations of the children's understanding of force and motion.

Giving children the opportunity to represent their thinking in different ways—i.e., orally, by drawing and painting, and by building a 3-D model—helps children understand the how, what and why of a concept. It also offers multiple entry points to accommodate different learning styles.

cultureCuepoints.cuepoint: Notice the teacher's request: "Alex, you gotta explain that." Without a lot of prior work on making it safe to say what you think when the teacher asks, this request would be intimidating to a child.

Notice that Alex is comfortable expressing his ideas. Although he is slightly wrong about the concepts, discussing them will help him refine his understanding and work toward a notion of potential energy being gained or lost as it trades off with kinetic energy (energy of motion).

The teacher realizes there is something that doesn't add up, but she doesn't tell the child he's wrong or correct him. Instead she tries to help him clarify his understanding by engaging him in dialogue.

Now the child realizes he isn't right, but he is still being candid. Although the stakes for embarassment are higher, he still says what he thinks. An effective classroom culture values learning as a process and allows children to revise their thinking through discussion and interaction.

Note that the teacher could have let the misconception pass, but she doesn't. Because she has established the classroom as a socially safe environment, she knows she can engage the whole group in the discussion.

Alex is saying that the message ball is gaining kinetic energy when it is going down. Notice he is still willing to share his ideas openly, even when he is in front of the whole class. Notice, too, that everyone is respectful as he speaks.

Here the teacher has noticed another child has something to say. Together the teacher and children construct a discussion in which children say what they think and no one attacks their ideas or pokes fun. The clear message is that the classroom is a safe place where thoughts can be expressed without negative consequences.

Notice how the teacher picks up on the child's question, "When it's going down it's going faster. So how is it losing speed?" When the teacher says, "That's confusing," she underscores the dissonance between the ideas and models how to think through a problem.
As discussions and re-teaching continue, the teacher will use what the children are saying to distinguish between speed and total energy and between kinetic and potential energy.

For more about the story of the roller coaster, go to the Flexible Planning video, which shows how the teachers did research to clarify their understanding of kinetic and potential energy and then brought the information to the children.

video.title: Classroom Space
video.story: This video depicts a variety of ways to set up the classroom space for teaching science for young children. Classroom space should be adaptable to support the science content and children's evolving ideas.

planningCuepoints.cuepoint: With a variety of spatial configurations, children can work on different aspects of a collaborative project simultaneously. In planning a project, it is important to think ahead about different ways the space--both inside and outside the classroom--can support the project.

Setting up the classroom to support a variety of activities requires formal planning. However, the more flexible the setup, the more effective it will be in adapting and responding to the needs of children and the ways in which they learn.

setupCuepoints.cuepoint: The strategic arrangement of cabinets and bookcases provides a space for children's imaginary play, a key component of young children's learning.
The positioning of students' large-scale creations (such as the blue Totem Pole) can help divide the classroom space and also provides a display of children's work.
A cozy space for reading (the sofa and coffee table seen here) helps make the classroom more appealing and bridges the transition from home to school.

A large area rug is used for whole-group learning and class discussions. It also offers a space for children to spread out while working independently. Tables and chairs (in the background on the left) provide an area for small groups to work together.
Looking at a bird's-eye view of the learning environment you just watched may help you understand how space can be arranged effectively to maximize the learning potential of your classroom.
To see a full-resolution version of this floorplan, go to the main CEE site, under Resources > Classroom Setup > Classroom Space Floorplan.

experiencesCuepoints.cuepoint: Including lots of books and comfortable reading spaces in the classroom setup encourages children to explore reading materials that support their firsthand and secondhand experiences.
Classrooms should be arranged so that relevant reading materials are readily accessible to children.
A large area rug provides a comfortable space for children to share a secondhand experience such as watching a video.
Incorporating computers into the classroom space, when possible, helps facilitate children's access to secondhand experiences, such as looking at photos or websites chosen by the teacher.

representationCuepoints.cuepoint: Children represent their understanding of concepts through dramatic play. Designating space for this kind of learning encourages children's imaginations and allows teachers to assess understanding.
Children's 3-D representation of a totem pole positioned in the classroom provides a reminder of the process and physical principles of construction, such as gravity, weight and balance.

A large clear space provides an area for kinesthetic representation. It also offers a gathering space for oral representation through discussion. Both provide opportunities for teachers to assess children's understanding.
Incorporating computers into the classroom space, when possible, gives children an additional medium for 2-D representation.

cultureCuepoints.cuepoint: Areas designed for small groups encourage student interactions and the development of positive social skills. This helps create a classroom culture where children feel comfortable exchanging ideas.
By moving about the room and checking in with children, the teacher helps them develop independence while also fostering a culture of respect and responsibility.
Providing children with a comfortable, inviting environment lets them know that they are valued and encourages their cooperative participation in the learning community.

video.title: Classroom Displays
video.story: This video depicts a variety of ways that classroom displays support the teaching of science for young children. Classroom displays should adapt to reflect the science content and children's evolving ideas.

planningCuepoints.cuepoint: Teachers should look beyond decoration and plan meaningful and functional displays that change along with the classroom.

Coming up with ways to include hands-on displays should be a part of the formal planning of classroom activities. To correspond with a unit about friction, teachers arranged for classroom families to donate simple materials like sand and scraps of fabric, which were glued to cardboard and displayed on a table to promote student engagement with the concepts.
Teachers planned for their students' 2D and 3D representations of textures to also function as a stimulating wall display.

Plan to take pictures of your students engaged in class projects. These photos can help children and teachers to reflect on their work, and they also help parents be informed members of the classroom community.

setupCuepoints.cuepoint: Classroom displays should be dynamic spaces for student work, as well as for thought-provoking objects that inspire children's thinking.
A table displaying hands-on books and materials becomes an interactive display designed to attract attention and encourage students' engagement.

Look for ways to allow individual and collaborative student projects to be the focus of your classroom display. Here, students used clay to represent words that describe characteristics of matter. The individual pieces are arranged to create a visual "chart" that supports students' thinking.
Keeping display boards simple and uncluttered allows children's work to be the focus. A bulletin board covered with busy patterns and colors can detract from the integrity of children's work.

Documenting learning processes and ongoing projects can also be an important part of classroom display. It encourages students to reflect on their thought processes and past work. Documentary display also allows teachers to reflect upon their practice.

Allowing ongoing projects to remain a part of the classroom display inspires children to continue thinking about the material throughout the school day. The presence of the rollercoaster on the outside windows of the classroom encourages children to discuss possible additions or changes, and keeps the concepts fresh in their minds.

experiencesCuepoints.cuepoint: Including books, posters, and 3D objects in your classroom displays provides children with experiences related to the curricular concepts. Here, teachers have set out simple inclined planes, small blocks of various shapes, and surfaces with different textures for children to explore, providing them with firsthand experiences.

Including reading materials and informational posters in classroom displays offers students thirdhand experiences that enhance their understanding of the concepts and provide background information for firsthand experiences.
Here, the classroom display includes photographs of students exploring the properties of different states of matter through firsthand experiences.

The display tells the story of a "solids hunt", where students went exploring outside and brought back a variety of items with different characteristics. They then categorized the items and wrote descriptions of them.

A student's representation of swings in motion reflects the child's firsthand experience on the playground. Including the representation in the classroom display reinforces for all the students that they experience the physical principles of force and motion every day.

representationCuepoints.cuepoint: Student representations of concepts are the cornerstone of classroom display. Making students' creative work visible in the classroom helps stimulate thinking and reinforces the concepts.
Students' 2-D representations, including labeled diagrams they create to represent their understanding, can be powerful components of a thought-provoking classroom display.

The students' 3D representation of a rollercoaster is mounted on the outside of the classroom, where it can remain while the building process continues. Displaying in-process projects like this one allows children to continually examine their work and add to it as they learn more about the concepts and big ideas.

As part of their unit on motion, the students collaborated on a large-scale mural on canvas, which represents their understanding of the physics at work at a local amusement park. The painting has become a permanent part of the school's hallway display.

cultureCuepoints.cuepoint: Classroom displays should feature hands-on objects to promote curiosity and engagement. This requires establishing a classroom culture early in the year where students respect classroom property and are trusted to use it appropriately.

Here, student representations are displayed as an informational chart that illustrates the various characteristics of matter. This type of display emphasizes students' work as a source of information, validating their efforts and showing that their contributions to the classroom are valued.

Documentation displays that show photographs of children at work help engage parents in the life of the classroom and make them part of the learning community. Here, parents can see their children engaged in a long-term project, and can follow the evolution of the project step-by-step.

video.title: Classroom Resources
video.story: This video depicts a variety of resources to be used in teaching science for young children. A variety of adaptable resources should be offered to support the science content and children's evolving ideas.

planningCuepoints.cuepoint: Thinking about what materials children will need in their work is an important part of planning. When planning for a long-term project, teachers should consider asking parents to bring in modest materials and scraps for the children's use.

To support children's understanding of solids, the teacher planned an experience in which she provided a variety of rocks for the children to sort into groups according to characteristics. She had the rocks waiting on tables for children when they returned from lunch so they could get to work right away.

In formal planning in the beginning of the year, the teacher arranged for every child to have a clipboard for recording observations. The sturdy clipboards can be taken on field trips and reused from year to year.
Teachers can work with their school or local librarian to select reading materials that enrich children's understanding of the concepts and big ideas.

Including resources such as wheels and axles in the dramatic play area helps ensure that even unstructured choice time provides an opportunity to enrich children's understanding of the concepts and big ideas.

setupCuepoints.cuepoint: Resources should include books, art supplies and an assortment of creative materials. To foster independence and creativity, children should be able to access resources when they need them and without assistance.

Grouping supplies in an attractive manner makes them inviting to children. It also inspires children to want to experiment with different media, which in turn enriches their work and provides multiple opportunities for assessment.

Resources are as much a part of the classroom's physical environment as the furniture and display boards. Their visibility is a constant reminder to children that thinking is an active process, and that ideas should be recorded, experimented with, evaluated and revised.

Book displays should be changed and updated to correspond with the subject matter taught in the classroom. Here, a selection of books about force and motion and simple machines provide information related to the concepts and big ideas.
A small table display provides stimulating, unusual and thought-provoking items that children may explore on their own.

Asking classroom families to bring in modest materials and scraps can be an inexpensive way to support a large-scale project. Designating a kid-friendly place in the classroom for these varied supplies broadens children's thinking and encourages creativity.

experiencesCuepoints.cuepoint: To support children's understanding of solids, the teacher set out materials for a firsthand experience in which children sorted a variety of rocks into groups according to characteristics.

Books about force and motion and simple machines provide thirdhand experiences to enrich children's understanding of the concepts and big ideas. Making reading materials readily available throughout the room encourages children to use books as a resource in their work and to explore science related materials during reading time.

A classroom setup that incorporates resources related to the concepts and big ideas encourages children to seek out firsthand experiences on their own. Observations and information gathered from these experiences can inform classroom discussions.

representationCuepoints.cuepoint: Keep in mind that no one medium offers the best means of expression for every child. Offering a wide variety of materials to be used in representation helps children convey their understanding of concepts and big ideas and also can give the teacher a more accurate assessment of children's understanding.
Clipboards are one way to provide a convenient and efficient way for children to record observations. The observations will later inform children's representations of the concepts and big ideas.
Including a selection of nonfiction books amongst other hands-on materials encourages children to see the books as reference tools to be used in creating representations.
Resources for large-scale representations can include a variety of donated materials. Using donated or found materials keeps costs low and inspires children to extend their thinking.

cultureCuepoints.cuepoint: Setting up spaces where materials are stored in an attractive and welcoming way encourages pride in the learning environment and inspires children's thinking.
Storing materials so that they are always at hand tells children that they are capable, responsible members of the classroom community and that they have important work to do.

Communicating expectations and setting routines supports a classroom culture where everyone takes responsibility for their surroundings. In turn, children should be trusted to treat classroom property with respect and to work as independently as possible.

video.title: Lunchtime Planning
video.story: All the K-1 teachers meet to discuss experiences students will need to acquire an understanding of different forces (i.e. gravity, friction, push, pull, etc.) and how these forces cause motion.
video.standards: The motion of objects can be observed and measured. As a basis for understanding this concept: a. Students know the position of an object can be described by locating it in relation to another object or to the background. b. Students know an object's motion can be described by recording the change in position of the object over time. c. Students know the way to change how something is moving is by giving it a push or a pull. The size of the change is related to the strength, or the amount of force, of the push or pull. d. Students know tools and machines are used to apply pushes and pulls (forces) to make things move. e. Students know objects fall to the ground unless something holds them up.

planningCuepoints.cuepoint: All the teachers from the K-1 grade level meet to plan experiences that will help children acquire knowledge of the concepts and big ideas. Allocating time for grade-level meetings requires the support of administrators.
Although one teacher starts the conversation, as it goes along everyone contributes different ideas.
Meeting as a group allows the teachers to share ideas. After their discussion, they will implement the ideas in ways that are suited to their students.

setupCuepoints.cuepoint: Teachers consider which materials and resources will be best suited to setting up firsthand experiences that illustrate the concepts.
A teacher suggests using a large Arrowhead water bottle because it is common to all the classrooms and is heavy enough to present a challenge for the children when they try to move it.
Using the playground equipment for experiences with force and motion extends the learning environment and helps children make connections between the concepts and the world around them.

experiencesCuepoints.cuepoint: K-1 teachers discuss what firsthand experiences to provide for the students to demonstrate different kinds of forces.
As the teachers consider different possibilities for experiences for the children, they anticipate how the children will react and what they will think while they are having the experiences.
Asking children to move one of the large Arrowhead water bottles in their classroom offers a hands-on task that can inspire "how" and "why" questions and lead to further exploration.
Once the teachers have given the children some background knowledge on force and motion, they will take the children to the playground for firsthand experiences to reinforce the concept.

representationCuepoints.cuepoint: Linking concepts and experiences in their planning discussions will help the teachers later as they assess the children's representations.
The experiences the teachers are planning will be followed by discussion, where children will have the opportunity to orally represent their understanding of the concepts.

cultureCuepoints.cuepoint: The teachers plan experiences that the children will share, which helps ensure everyone has background knowledge of the concepts and provides context for their discussions.

Notice that the teacher anticipates the children will realize the easiest way to move the water bottle will be to roll it. She talks about honoring their response and then asking them to try another way.

video.title: Potential Potential Potential
video.concept: Energy changes from one form to another
video.story: In the sequence before this video begins, students pointed out areas of potential and kinetic energy on the model roller coaster outside their classroom, and teachers realized there were misunderstandings regarding the concepts (for more on this, see the Example Video for Teacher-Student Culture). Taking advantage of a teachable moment, teachers decided to re-introduce the concepts to clear up the misconceptions. Before the concepts are presented again to the students, however, the teachers want to make sure their own understanding is correct, and so they consult with a physics expert.
video.standards: Energy and matter have multiple forms and can be changed from one form to another. As a basis for understanding this concept: a. Students know sources of stored energy take many different forms, such as food, fuel, and batteries. c. Students know machines and living things convert stored energy to motion and heat. d. Students know energy can be carried from one place to another by waves, such as water waves and sound waves, by electric current, and by moving objects.

planningCuepoints.cuepoint: Upon realizing a common misconception in their students' understanding of kinetic and potential energy, the teachers take time to review the concepts.
Next the teachers gather the students to address the confusion and clarify the concepts. The teachers have cleared class time for this essential discussion.

At the end of the discussion, one child noted that the transformation of energy is similar to when he and his friends run up and down a hill near the school. The teachers capitalize on the student's insight and take the class to the hill for an impromptu experience that helps reinforce the concepts.

setupCuepoints.cuepoint: The rug area provides a space where the teacher can gather the whole class to clarify the concepts. Here she is able to observe children's reactions and check in that everyone is getting the information.
Taking the children to a grassy hill near the school extends the learning space beyond the classroom.
Being flexible in her planning allows the teacher to pick up on a student's suggestion and results in using a space that is especially well suited to exploring the concepts.

experiencesCuepoints.cuepoint: As the teacher speaks, she refers to a diagram of a roller coaster, which she labels. Looking at the diagram is a thirdhand experience for the children, giving them a visual representation of abstract concepts.

As part of their firsthand experiences related to the concepts, the class visited a local amusement park. Recalling their experiences riding roller coasters helps the children make sense of the diagram.
Following a student's suggestion, the teachers take the children to a nearby hill so that they can personally experience the transformation of energy in their bodies as they run up and down.

representationCuepoints.cuepoint: The teacher and student refer to the teacher's 2-D representation of a roller coaster as they discuss the concepts.

At the end of the classroom discussion the teacher took the children outside to the 3-D representation of a roller coaster that they had made. She had them identify the sections of the representation where kinetic and potential energy are used.

The teacher requires the children to use formal academic language to describe the movement of matter--potential and kinetic energy--as they run up and down the hill. This reinforces the concepts through two kinds of representation--oral and kinesthetic.

cultureCuepoints.cuepoint: In an effective Classroom-Ecosystem, teachers see themselves as continual learners. By consulting with a member of the classroom community who is more expert in physics, the teachers enhance their knowledge and are better able to help the children understand physics.

When teachers and children are constructing knowledge together, it is sometimes necessary to change the plan for the day. Here the teacher has postponed a planned experience so the class can gather for a discussion to clarify the concepts.
Providing opportunities for children to connect the concepts to familiar activities helps make the concepts more meaningful.

video.title: The Project
video.story: K-1 teachers from adjoining classrooms meet to discuss possibilities for a long-term project through which students will demonstrate their understanding of the concepts.
video.standards: The motion of objects can be observed and measured. As a basis for understanding this concept: c. Students know the way to change how something is moving is by giving it a push or a pull. The size of the change is related to the strength, or the amount of force, of the push or pull. d. Students know tools and machines are used to apply pushes and pulls (forces) to make things move. e. Students know objects fall to the ground unless something holds them up.

subtitleCuepoints.cuepoint: I thought then, the next step would be to talk to the children about how we could make-- what they could design for our classroom,
or outside the classroom like in the block area, or in the playground, to make their play or the work easier.
And this is where I can put math in. You could try it the way it exists now, and then time it to see if the thing, the thing they make, does it make it faster?
Or, which is faster, which is slower?
That's a great idea.

Let's just talk for a minute. What's our goal? If we start with that, we can think about where to guide them next.
I know that we want to, the kids to engage in a long-term project, and that long-term project will be about designing, building...
It's to make work easier.
Easier. That's the goal.

planningCuepoints.cuepoint: Many times project ideas generate from the children through conversation and discussion. Other times, teachers ask the students thought-provoking questions that will stimulate ideas for a long-term project.
Teachers discuss the main concept that will be reinforced for the students through the project.

setupCuepoints.cuepoint: The teacher is thinking about using different areas inside and outside the classroom for the project. Depending on what the children decide, the areas will be modified to fit the project design.
After the teachers talk to the children about what they will build, they will do further project planning to determine what resources they need to implement the project.

experiencesCuepoints.cuepoint: The teacher is thinking about how to design experiences around the project that would integrate other curricular areas.
Planning for this long-term project comes after children have had many experiences that introduced and reinforced the concepts.

representationCuepoints.cuepoint: Oftentimes, teachers choose how students will represent their understanding of a concept or big idea. However, there are times when teachers ask students to choose how they want to demonstrate their knowledge. Student choice is a significant part of the process in long-term projects.
The process of designing and building the project will provide many opportunities for teachers to assess children's understanding of the concepts.
Earlier in the year, children designed simple toys as 3-D representations of the concept that simple machines make work easier.

cultureCuepoints.cuepoint: Asking children to contribute their ideas to the project design helps them to be more invested in the work and more likely to develop a deep understanding of the concepts.
Focusing the project on children's play or work helps make the concepts less abstract and encourages the children to make connections between science and their everyday lives.
All the children will contribute to the classroom project. This provides a natural way to help them develop collaborative skills.

video.story: During their study of simple machines, force and motion, and kinetic and potential energy, students decided to build a roller coaster that sends messages from one classroom to another. In this video, two children are working on the roller coaster model.
video.standards: The motion of objects can be observed and measured. As a basis for understanding this concept: a. Students know the position of an object can be described by locating it in relation to another object or to the background. b. Students know an object's motion can be described by recording the change in position of the object over time. c. Students know the way to change how something is moving is by giving it a push or a pull. The size of the change is related to the strength, or the amount of force, of the push or pull. d. Students know tools and machines are used to apply pushes and pulls (forces) to make things move. e. Students know objects fall to the ground unless something holds them up.

planningCuepoints.cuepoint: When the children came up with the idea to build a roller coaster, the teachers did project planning to ensure that there would be many opportunities for learning about the science concepts and big ideas.
In their project planning, teachers asked families to contribute scrap materials for use in building the roller coaster.

Part of the planning process was to group children into committees. These two students volunteered for the Building Committee. Committees are a good way to incorporate small-group work into class projects, and they mirror practices used in the adult workplace.

setupCuepoints.cuepoint: Teachers and children work on the roller coaster outside. Using outdoor space extends the learning environment and allows teachers and small groups to engage in detailed, concentrated work with fewer distractions.

Students and teachers chose to mount the roller coaster in a space where they can have easy, on-going access to it. This allows them to make revisions as needed and helps create an on-going dialogue about the project and the concepts.
The materials for the project are varied and accessible to all the children. The teacher encourages the children to decide which materials will work best for their purpose.
The materials include a jumble of donated scraps. Using donated and found materials keeps project costs low and inspires children to use creativity and imagination.

experiencesCuepoints.cuepoint: Working with a 3-D model provides children with firsthand experiences that make the concepts more tangible. Here the children can observe firsthand the effects of force and motion and the operation of simple machines such as inclined planes.

The students' building and testing of the roller coaster model is informed by previous experiences designed to illustrate the concepts. It also will provide context and help deepen understanding as they continue to explore the concepts and big ideas.

representationCuepoints.cuepoint: The model roller coaster is a 3-D representation of concepts such as force causes motion and simple machines make work easier.

Before beginning construction of the roller coaster, the children created 2-D representations of the components, such as inclined planes. In their drawings and paintings the children recorded their observations and then used those observations to inform the building of their 3-D representations.

The students' testing leads to observations about what makes sections of the roller coaster function, and this in turn leads to revisions to the model. Revising their 3-D representations allows children to deepen their understanding and formulate new questions.

cultureCuepoints.cuepoint: Although a teacher is present to supervise, the children are trusted to work on testing and improving the model roller coaster the group is building. They are able to work independently and productively because the teachers have set up routines to support this and children have had much practice working together.
Notice that the task requires the children to work cooperatively to solve the problem of how to get the ball through the tube. Real work in the world requires collaboration.

Notice how the children negotiate ideas, making suggestions and in turn being open to suggestions. Again, this kind of cooperative work is made possible by giving children many opportunities to work together.
The task engages the children and sustains their interest because it is in the context of a project they and their peers have generated.
